Great cycling path. Fresh air, great view, connects you to the downtown where you can enjoy some good wines.
I took this from my hotel into town, couldn't be any easier making it to downtown for some wine tastings!

This is a great path, it runs from Shoreline Park all the way down to the Bird refuge in Montecito. If you want to go down to the bird refugee on the south (east really side), at the East Beach Café, and the volleyball courts across the street you can go along the pathway in
Got out to get fresh air during Covid. We rode the path twice. Riding in town got a little scary with cars around.

This is a great place to walk on a nice day.   A lot of restaurants, shops and hotels along  the way to explore.  The weekend are busy and the Sunday craft market is fun to stroll through.  The sunrise was beautiful to see from this area.
I enjoyed walking this each morning , it is well paved and nice view of Santa Barbara and the ocean.
We rode bikes several times while in Santa Barbara, as well as walked back and forth.  This is such a nice option!

It is as safe, well-maintained, beautifully scenic and wonderfully located as one can find in a famous town alongside a famous beach on an old highway. Keep your wits about you, be polite and have fun along this gorgeous strip in lovely Santa Barbara.

The bike path was awesome on Cabrillo! This was one of the best highlights of our trip. You ride right along the beach and harbor. We also got to see the bird refuge. We rented cruiser bikes for $10/ hr.
The Cabrillo Bike Path was a wonderful way to see the coast. Pleasant, well used but not over crowded.

Santa Barbara did an excellent job of providing for a bike friendly environment. They should be a model for others cities on how to make cycling safe and fun. The trail along the beach to the harbor area is beautiful.
We hit this area on our way down from San Francisco cycling the coast to San Diego. The path is beautiful and clean and was refreshing to ride it through SB off the roads a bit.

This "bike" path is fabulous for biking OR walking.  If biking, it is relatively flat and easy even for geriatric bikers.  We start at the far west end of Shoreline Park and bike along the beaches, past the Andree Clark reserve, turn at the sign to the Music Academy of the West
I could have rode my bike all day long.  It was easy to rent bikes off state street and we rode for 2 hours.  All around the harbor, wharf and up north on the bluff.
Well marked, had a blast. I could tell there were many locals out on their daily walk, several with signs asking tourists to respect posted signs. It was easily marked where bikes were acceptable.

I ran on this path multiple times, and as a family we biked it for an hour.  It takes you by Stearns Wharf, by the Harbor, and by beautiful seashore. Everyone is low-key and relaxed; there's no one shouting "on your left!" or whizzing by at top speeds, so it's easy to enjoy the

It doesn't take very long and felt so good to get out and exercise after several days of rain, wine tours and fabulous dinners   We rented bikes from our hotel and (Biltmore) and road to the pier in the early morning   One of the highlites of my short trip to Santa Barbara
Rent a bike from your hotel and enjoy the coastline on a very safe bike path. You may experience a little uphill parts. But it should not be too hard for anybody even vaguely fit

A great way to see the city and its adjoining marina area is to rent a bike and ride all or parts of this picturesque bike path.
Right parallel to the beach, great view, Just best to go off-season, otherwise it is over crowded & difficult to traverse

Chaucer's is the only place in SB that is a must-visit EVERY time we come into town. Endless rows of books and the most comprehensive poetry section I've ever encountered.

Great book selection, very knowledgeable and friendly staff.  I can always find the book I'm looking for a Chaucer's, and about three others that I take home because they look amazing!  The staff in the children's section also also great at recommending books that kids will love.
I love Chaucers. I always find an interesting book, and leave with a lot more than I planned on! The staff can help you find anything and the store is stocked with great books.

We ALWAYS buy our books and gifts at Chaucers. We believe that purchasing online puts small businesses out of business. BOOKS are considered in our family as "sacred ground" and I wouldn't dream of buying a book from Amazon. Share the wealth you know!
I love book stores. I know we can just order from Amazon, but there isn't anything like browsing a book store in person. This is a good one.

The staff is super nice, and its the last book store left in SB. They have an awesome selection and can order anything they dont have. I love to visit to read in store sometimes , just a great place to be,

The good folks of Chaucer's Bookstore are always pleasant, informative and helpful. Their staff are always eager to help you find your favorite author, or book, assist with great reading suggestions and place special orders if your particular title is not in stock. Chaucer's is
Great selection. I buy most all my crossword puzzlebooks here. Terrific selection. Located in the Lorreto shopping center on State Street near Las Positas.
Best thing for me was the extensive collection of cook books...crowded, cozy independent book store with something for everyone.
Whether you are browsing for the next best beach book, looking for local heritage information or just want to find that special book, this is the place for you

Chaucer's is an old school bookstore.  It's no Barnes and Noble.  There is no espresso bar.  None of that.  Just a ton of dusty old shelves cared for lovingly by a bunch of folks who love books.  I think the prices are reasonably competitive with the on-line sellers.  Go there.
In this day of online retail, it is satisfying to find a bookstore that has it all including children's books and a staff that is more than helpful.
Old school bookstore with stacks of books on every subject. You can browse and read all day long to your hearts content
Chaucer's has a very friendly and knowledgeable staff.  It's an experience whether you end up purchasing a book for just browse and chat with staff.
Great selection of books! The staff is VERY friendly and knowledgeable. If you like book stores that are welcoming and comfortable and just has a laid-back vibe, than this store is for you.

Chaucer’s is a throwback. It’s a bookstore that sells new books but has the comfortable, lived-in feel of a used bookstore.   Books lining the aisles, books stacked on the tops of shelves, posters on the walls, all contribute to the neighborhood, non-corporate feel.   We’re glad
Really great bookstore. This is one of the the last really great true bookstores. I know amazon has put everyone out of business. Its worth going in!
It has many books to match everybody's intereses. They also can order one that they don't have. Nice selection of stationery, callenders, etc.

Chaucer’s has been around for decades and we hope they will stay open forever.  They have every book you can think of, and if they don’t.....they will order it.  They have great greeting cards and a few gift items.  Can’t recommend them highly enough.
Nothing particularly special about this store.  Not sure why its rated so highly.  They did not have a current best seller in stock.

This is one of the best bookstores I have visited, with a wide variety of displays and extensive collection.  Also they have a good selection of literary magazines, I just purchased the Tin House final edition.  I like to patronize bookstores in every town I visit and was really

If you are looking for a good book, this is the place to go.  Good service, great selection and relevant suggestions.  If your town doesn't have a good independent bookstore, stop by to see what you are missing.

In an age of shopping online Chaucer's gives me hope that old style business has a place in the world of consumerism. This locally owned business of many years offers customer service, an impressive inventory given the space, and a commitment to support growing literacy in our
I love this bookstore and amazed that it is survived after Barnes and Nobles and Borders are not longer in existence in this town.

One of the last book stores where you can meander through the aisles and taste the many literary treats.  The clerks are friendly and knowledgeable with a children's section along with a plethora of topic sections.

POI_address: Montecito and Chapala Streets, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: We were on a bus tour and only stopped for a short time. The tour guide gave us interesting information about the tree. It truly is fascinating. Next time in Santa Barbara we plan on going back to spend some time at the tree to better appreciate it and learn more about it.

POI_address: Montecito and Chapala Streets, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: My father visited this tree before shipping ot in WWII and touched it and believed it kept him safe. It became a family tradition that you had to the "touch" the tree to have a safe trip when ever we drove through Santa Barbera. This has been happening now for four generations.

A short walk from our motel, we enjoyed walking our dog along the beach and to the outdoor wine bars.
wine tasting with lovely outdoor patios and multiple breweries on top of artisan shopping with one of a kind hand crafted items from leather, to jewelry, to clothing, etc. What a fun place!!!
Lots of variety but tough for parking.   We hit several local businesses and had fun walking all the eclectic options.

The Funk Zone is a great place to visit. There are several excellent wineries and breweries in the area.  There are also some great restaurants and small local shops.We never visit Santa Barbara without going to the Funk Zone.

Easy to walk around and you can find a guide on line for the wine tasting or pick one up in hotel or i office. Not your usual posh relaxed wine tastings here. More frenetic bars with tastings available. Obviously where the young and beautiful hang out.

This was a fun stop on our California coastal adventure. There were plenty of places to grab a beer and or wine. Our hotel shuttle dropped us off and picked us up which was super convenient.   It’s close to the beach as well so you can take a stroll near the water too.   Each
This is a lovely area down by the beach. Many cool shops, restaurants and wine tasting. We enjoyed poking around here for a couple of hours.
Loved going from one charming place to another in this area full of wine bars.  Great for a few drinks on a nice night.

Didn't feel enticed enough to stop by so just drove through it...could be better at night during an art show or something. It's in an industrial area so didn't really feel safe but some of the art was interesting driving by.
Lots of very cool restaurants, shops and galleries.  We took a tour through the Funk Zone, and had a great time!
We loved hanging out in this area. So cool!  Great little tasting rooms for wineries, brewing companies and food. Everywhere we went was FABULOUS!  We had a truly great time!

This is the part of Santa Barbara that I visit every time I return!  Here you will find the best restaurants, the most interesting shops, and the best wind-tasting available in SB!

Excellent, quaint area of Santa Barbara! Great for those who like eclectic food and great wine! This was my second time there and, once again it did not disappoint! The Lark and Les Marchands are two of my favorite restaurants!
Funk Zone offers the ability to visit shops restaurants wine outlets and all within a walking distance

This is such a unique area of Santa Barbara.  It's not too far from the pier.  There are many great shops, bars, and cafes.

This area seems to be just developing. It's mostly wine tasting places so we didnt spend much time here. There are a few restaurants and shops too. The shops are funky hipster style store so fun if you're into that style.
We were very impressed with Kunin Winery tastings. Santa Barbara Winery has good choices and flights.
Did some wine tasting at the Santa Barbara Winery.  Friendly staff and fabulous wines. Great walk fro our hotel and intersting section of town.  The Funk Zone fits it perfectly.

This is a fun area to walk around during the day or night.  Many local wine tasting rooms (including Area 51) and at least one local brewery with sports bar.  Food trucks are nearby if you want to bring some food into your tasting.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: If I were a local with a dog I would probably gives this place 5 stars. Looks like a great place to take your dog off-leash. As a tourist, it was a nice, easy walk with some great views but I was hoping the trail was longer.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: This is a great spot for walks by the ocean. The views on a clear day are gorgeous. The only reason for my 4/5 stars is that a lot of dogs are off leash in the preserve and I've seen a couple of fights because of this, however, I would still highly recommend.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: We enjoyed the DFP in May and had a beautiful afternoon to hike and enjoy the ocean view.  The hike is fairly easy, a bit of an elevation increase, and be sure to wear comfortable & good walking shoes.  Bravo to the family for preserving nature for all to enjoy.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: For dog owners- a must do. For others without dogs, it’s Flat walk... a lot of dead trees. Best part was the dogs looked happy and the ocean was beautiful. Dusty and not very interesting.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: We found this off the beaten path, beautiful, ocean-front bluff park a bit by chance, but vote its vistas in the top five SB (perhaps top ten in all Caly). As it is an off-leash dog area, our dog votes this the best part of our trip, we are close in agreeing it was a special

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: What a beautiful, easy hike to an amazing cliff top view of the ocean. Dogs are allowed off leash so there were tons of dogs running around enjoying themselves or running with their owners. It was awesome! We met many friendly people and also just relaxed and enjoyed the view.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: Visiting the area ... recommended to explore this area. Had a great walk perched above the ocean ...

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: I was looking forward to this trail but unfortunately the dog owners don’t obey the rules. I was walking along the trail in the “dog leash on” area. As I walked the trail a pit bull was starting to approach me. I turned away and started walking then another medium sized dog

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: What a nice little Preserve in Santa Barbara.  We just followed the GPS driving direction on YELP and parked in the residential area where instructed.  This put us right at the entrance of the preserve.  It is used by a lot of dog walkers, but they all were very courteous of us

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: On the cliff above the ocean, the Douglas Family Preserve is open spaces with walking trails through wooded areas.  It is a place for dogs and owners to run together as well as an occasional hawk, rabbit and gopher!

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: This is a must do in SB.  Beautiful vista views of beach.  Very dramatic and stunning.   A great way to spend a morning.  Hike is easy and take the camera!

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: Walked Shadow and Mae, two of my friends dogs at sunset.  The sunset was beautiful.  Fresh  smells of sage mixed with the ocean.  The famous “Santa Barbara light” filtered through the eucalyptus trees. We could hear some beautiful singing and suddenly we came to see 8-9 college

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: Parking is done on the side of the road in this neighborhood. It has wide trails to the ocean through eucalyptus trees. Dogs run free.

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: This is a nice quiet place to take a decent walk with many views of the ocean and Arroyo Burro beach below.  Most people are walking their dogs - all of whom were very well behaved.  There are lots of trails to choose from, but it's a small enough place, that you won't get lost

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: This is a great spot to hike along the coast. The weather was perfect when I went. You can do many things here and stay for hours. A true hidden gem located on a cliff with the ocean and Arroyo Burro Beach below. There are various entrances to take into the preserve. Situated in

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: The Douglas Family Preserve is kind of a "best kept secret" usually known just by locals. This is a wonderful place to walk your dog, off leash or just take a walk yourself. It is located at the end of Mesa School Lane, off of Cliff Drive in Santa Barbara.  You park your car in

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: Douglas Family Preserve sits above the Arroy Burro Beach County Park and Hendry's Beach.  The Preserve itself is a nice, relatively flat walk with ocean vistas and a paths near a rich stand of live oaks and other trees.     We recommend making it part of a loop.  Park in the

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: We walked here from downtown SB and really enjoyed the exercise. I was a bit worried about this part of our journey as I knew there was an off-leash bit. But, I had nothing to worry about. Although there were oodles of dogs here, they were all well-behaved happy chappies. One

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: We ( Husband, 2 teens, and I) visited this reserve upon the advice of several Trip Advisor reviewers.  We were not disappointed.  The reserve does not look like much when you first enter-- but amble on and you will be rewarded with postcard-worthy vistas of the mountains and

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: You don't have to have a dog, but Douglas Preserve is a dog park where dogs can be off leash.  Really beautiful.  Just be sure to pick up after your dog!

POI_address: Mesa School Lane, Santa Barbara, CA 93109
POI_reviews: For locals this is a go to place, especially for dog walkers and hang gliders, but for really anyone on any kind of day. Foggy or sunny- any season. Solo or with family!  Sometimes when the parking lot at Hendry's beach below is too crowded in summer and holidays  -we just drive

Was looking for some good stairs in the area to keep up my exercise routine while away and wow!! These are such a fun alternative!! I’m so glad I found them and will definitely be back! So, the name is a tad misleading - there aren’t one thousands steps - there are around 150

GPS took us to the general location but it took asking locals to find the entry to the steps from the cliff down to the water.  When we got there, high tide brought the crashing waves up onto the steps, the beach was completely under water.  Not actually a thousand steps but a
It is true not everyone knows about this place so love going down to the beach and just hanging out.

This beach is so calm and beautiful. Perfect for a walk with the dog and very close friends. The steps down to the beach are the perfect entry to this place.  Use caution going down the stairs when they are wet, they are very slippery.

This is an incredibly beautiful beach. It is a moderate walk so don't let the 1000 steps dissuade you. It reminds me of the beaches around LaJolla San Diego as well as Stanley Park Vancouver. It was really tranquil during our visit. The cliffs towering above gave it a really

It’s not a thousand steps down, but my calves will tell you it’s plenty. There is a restroom and drinking water at the bottom, nothing too great, but it’s the beach. Beautiful beach, rocks, tide pools, lots to hike.

1000 Step Beach that is not really a 1000 steps, LOL, but is definitely worth the trip to walk and explore. It is beautiful, clean, peaceful and not a lot of people (at least the day we went). Here's a couple helpful hints that may be useful.  1) A MUST, check when High tide and
This place is worth the trek down the stairs. We went a high tide and the view was spectacular.  Quiet beach, not a lot of people. Best part of my trip
I love going to this beach because it’s so beautiful but make sure you are rested before you start to back up those stairs cause they can be brutal on the legs, lol!
I counted the steps and it is nowhere near 1000, which is a good thing, as it still it tough coming up. You'll want to keep an eye on the tides as the beach completely disappears here at high tide.

A delightful grand beautiful by cluffs and sea walk ...  Long stairways down or up need to go at lower tide though ...  Can walk from thousand steps all the way to Shoreline all the way to Ledbetter which is fabulous
We walk or run here once a week. It is gorgeous. There is a great bar nearbye, and the water is almost always calm.

Very clean and breathtaking views. Quite and very relaxing great place to just unwind. A little but tough to find parking but worth the walk. Be ready to walk down lots of stairs.... then back up at the end of the day.

I grew up in Santa Barbara and now come back to visit family here. I used to go to this beach as a kid and loved it for the beauty, tide pools, waves and privacy.  Nowadays it's not super crowded but not peaceful as there just more people in town these days, there are more dogs

I walk the beaches along the Mesa most every morning. If I'm energetic I like 1000 steps. BTW... it's actually closer to 400 steps in reality.   You can only walk the beach when the tide is out so check your tide charts first. It is worth the wait as you'll find tide pools and

Really impressive beach. We really enjoyed seeing the cave and all of the multi million dollar beach houses, some of which have elevators to get rich home owners to and from the beach faster.   The challenge of this beach is the parking. You have to park on the side of PCH and
Nice and very clean. We love the walk on the beach and were able to climb on the steps with a very brief break lol

Not exactly 1000 steps, but was up for the challenge. Need to be very careful when going down the stairs...but when you do...paradise awaits! Didn't check the tide, a little high, but was still able to walk on the beach. So relaxing and the view amazing.  Definitely need to

The thousand step beach is actually 150 stone steps down to the beach. There are no rails and the steps are very worn in some places and slippery when wet. No access at high tide so make sure you don't get caught. Not good for strollers. Also a lot of tar on the beach so make
Thousand Steps Beach is Worth the Steps! The views are amazing and the fresh salty sea air sometimes cooler - so dress in layers!
Plenty of dog walkers and not all were diligent about cleaning up after their animals. At least the beach is cleaned by the tide daily!
There is not a lot of shoreline here, but is still a beautiful beach to visit. Don't mind the steps, they really aren't that bad.

Sure feels like a 1000 steps when you head back up to street level. We stayed close and could walk to the access stairs. Nice quiet location away from the main beach area by the marina. Would recommend this location for quiet time and a perfect place to let the kids play.

Ok, it might not be 1000 steps but it sure seemed like it. I was surprised to see the elderly making the jaunt down and back up. The beach is pretty vacant since it takes some effort to come back up. Go it you can.

Our hotel front desk clerk recommended this place too us.  If you didn't know it was there, you could easily miss it.  So after breakfast, we ventured out to find it.  Even though it says 1000 steps, (which my husband was really worried about climbing back up) it wasn't more

This is a must-see place for a real orchid enthusiast. Nothing wrong, but not for "I buy orchids mostly at Kroger or Lowes"  kind of clientele. A few comments here are from people who are obviously very confused or have no idea what they are talking about. This is a real

Years ago I grew orchids under lights while living in Minnesota.  I learned of this site from Tripadvisor.  It is open to the public without admission charge!  There is a wide array orchids for your leisurely enjoyment.

Family owned giant spread of every kind of orchid you can imagine. We stop here every time we visit Santa Barbara. It’s hard to leave without buying a new specimen.  The small staff (family every time we’ve been there) are very knowledgeable and will be delighted to answer your

This is a legendary landmark founded by one of the greats in the orchid field and is a must-see destination for amateur and professional orchid enthusiasts.  The owners are deeply and generously involved in promoting the study and appreciation of orchids.
Since this is an indoor botanical garden of marvelous variety of orchids, don't be dissapointed not to see butterflies.
If you love orchids - this is YOUR PLACE. This is for the person who genuinely wants to see a variety of orchids in a greenhouse type setting, and be able to purchase them. It's free and beautiful.
What a great nursery to walk around and enjoy the wide selection of orchids. The staff is friendly and very knowledgeable.  I enjoy each visit.

It's a little bit of a drive, but well worth it to see the countless number of beautiful orchids!!  we were there 2 weeks before the orchid festival so many of them were in bloom.  it is a must-see if you love orchids!

Lovely orchids for miles!  A literal feast for the eyes.  You can buy plants or cut orchids or just revel in the beauty.  Always a fun place to visit and even more so during the annual Orchid Show time.
It was my birthday and the kids and grand kids stopped her and got me a orchid as a surprise.  It is awesome and very healthy and beautiful.

The Orchid Estate sits near More Mesa and is open for visitors.  They've been hybridizing and growing orchids for year; the place is teeming with orchids.  It is an explosion of color and kind, and a fun place to walk around.  The staff are friendly, knowledgable and totally

I like orchids.....  maybe not passionate about them.....but if I lived nearby Santa Barbara Orchid Estate, it could become an addiction.    Prices are quite reasonable for some beautiful specimens, starting around $25 and going way up for rare, one-of-a-kind plants.   It's

Luckily a local told us about the Orchid Estate. It's a family owned business with an incredible variety of orchids, many for sale. The owners were very hospitable and helpful, taking the time to answer our many questions.  The garden is huge with hundreds of types of orchids.

The most amazing collection and variety of orchids available to the public. It was fun just walking through it and photographing the flowers. We bought a very special orchid and had it shipped home. If you like orchids, don't miss this place!

Based on previous reviews I thought this would be something like a botanical garden.  But when we arrived the owner seemed frustrated with us because we were just there to look and not buy.  Most areas had signs that said "no admittance".  We left after about 15 minutes.  But

I had met Wayne, one of the owners, and his father at an orchid show in Pasadena over a year ago. He recognized me (for real - he remembered what I do for a living) and was very helpful on this visit. Although they supply wholesale orchids countrywide, Wayne took a lot of time

Unfortunately, we visited the estate when barely anything was in bloom. However, the orchids we did see were really incredible. We expected the entire estate, though, to be better cared for. It seems disorganized and downtrodden. If someone spiffed-up the place a bit, I think
If you are an orchid lover, then this is definitely a place to see once in your life. Absolutely beautiful specimens of orchids and such fascinating species of them as well!

This is the second visit; and well worth it if you are an orchid fan.  The people let you walk through the green houses on your own.  You can purchase orchids and have them shipped.  The person at the site was very well versed in orchids.  A fun, simple time.
Only over 1,00 different species of orchids.  Pretty amazing for a Missouri native.  This is a nursery with very helpful workers everywhere you turn.

I was told they have the most varieties in the world, which I am sure is true, though many if not most were not in bloom. I did, however, love the orchids that were in bloom. Pricey for my pocketbook, but since I was told they go all over the world to find them I am sure they

A must see for orchid lovers. An amazing collection and variety of orchids, always a bunch blooming. Good orchids are expensive, so if you want to buy keep that in mind. This was my second trip there, and it was just as wonderful as the first.

We stopped in this morning and have never seen so many orchids.  We didnt know that some have a wonderful scent.  Wayne helped us pick out a couple for our particular growing situation.  The staff was very helpful and we were really wowed

This was one of the most precious and lush nurseries ever been to.  All the orchids were gorgeous and so many of them deserved their own picture.   The ladies who ran the nursery were very inviting and warm, plus extremely informative.   No matter what your price range is there

We went here with another couple, expecting to see some nice orchids. We were unprepared for the variety and vast number of orchids they had. They also have orchids for purchase and we wished we could buy some...just couldn't figure out how to get them back home on a plane.

We picked this one just because I liked the outside patio.  Turns out the patio was full but we sat inside with the barrels.  Even better.  Wine tasting is so cheap compared to Napa. But just as good.  The ladies pouring the wine know their stuff and couldn’t be any friendlier.

I enjoyed this winery for the vibe, the wines and the breadsticks... plus you get to keep your wine glass for the $13 tasting price. I was not excited about the tasting rooms after visiting the beautiful wineries but this one was great and I would definitely return.
Love! Love! Love! This winery!  Everyone was super nice! Even gave us a tasting that was not on the list. Which was good since I bought 2 bottles of it! 😄

Santa Barbara is such a quaint community in and of itself, but the wineries (Funk Zone) is like nothing I've ever experienced.  If you are ever there, you need to visit this Winery.  It's worth every penny and the wine is fabulous
I wanted to get wine shipped back East to a relative.  They were so helpful at this winery and made my arrangements extremely easy.

We were told to do a wine tasting while we were here in Santa Barbara and we heard this was the better one. The wine was lovely and we got to sample quite a few. The samples were quite small compared to other wine tastings we have done in Europe.

We stopped in Santa Barbara on our way to LA. We saw this place and went in to check it out. It’s a cute place and spent 45 mins there doing a wine tasting.   You can hang out there as long as you want or just stay for a short duration.  I did the white wine tasting and their
This was a stop on The Urban Wine Trail.  Mark was very helpful and knowledgeable.  The tasting room cat is adorable and I loved the gift shop area.
I liked how the winery was decorated, PROMOT service, and the easibility in redeeming the wine tasting tour that I purchased through trip advisor.

The last time we were at SB Winery I received an emergency call and had to leave. We paid for our wine tasting after only one taste and left. The server told us to keep the card (marked paid) and use it next time as we had 4 tastes left.  Well, when we returned the server said

This is the first winery we stopped for wine tasting and it turned out that we ended up joining their wine club.  We came here 12 years ago and we were not impressed with their wines. This time their wines were amazing and perfect. All the wines we tasted were excellent. All the

We started a walking wine tour at the Santa Barbara Winery. The tasting price was fair and they let you keep your glass. There is no seating inside, you stand for your tasting. You can however sit outside on their patio with wine you purchase. The tasting was not very

Such a fun thing to do when in town!  Walking distance from beach area or downtown (trolley is always available and passes right by the street). Several tasting rooms, restaurants and live bands. Super casual and a whole of fun. Expect a lot of people including families with

A beautiful winery tasting room in downtown Santa Barbara in the funkiest little spot.  The weather was good enough to sit out on their patio where we enjoyed a glass and a tasting.   Reds and whites are both worth trying.  And they have very friendly and knowledgeable staff and

A local friend is a member so we were able to get free tastings.  They do not have a vineyard so this seems like one of the only ways to try their wines.  It was busy and a bit noisy yet glad we popped in.  The area is busy with hardly any parking so we took an Uber - very slick.

First, the experience there would vastly improve if they had 2 or so staff, who stand lazily behind the bar and gab with one another, that would serve outside on the patio instead. But that is a pie-in-the-sky wish; mostly I would have appreciated better simple service. During
Our last stop for the day on our urban wine trail. Super cute, super nice people, excellent wines and a friendly winery cat!  It’s Santa Barbara’s oldest winery as well, so definitely worth a stop.

This was a definite stop for us since it was rated as one of the better Wine Tastings. Our person was very knowledgeable of the local wines. Several of their wines were excellent. Sitting out on their patio with our favorite wine was a treat.

POI_reviews: This little hidden jewel is far off the hwy, up a windy road, but worth the trip to see it.  No place for parking, you have to pull off the road in a clear area, walk down to the cave to be able to see it.  Once there you have a slot to be able to stick your camera through to

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: I've been driving by Painted Cave Road for close to 50 years.  The wife and I finally took the road and stopped to see the cave.  The paintings in the cave are amazing!  This entire detour off Highway 154 can be done in 30 minutes.  Those 30 minutes are well the time.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Well it's a tiny cave, but this is an important piece of Chumash Indian history. It's directly on the road and easy to visit. Nothing else to see or do at this location but this would be an activity to do while in the neighborhood for a visit to Knapp's Castle (its trailhead is

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: The cave paintings were interesting; but there is not much else to see and do in this park.  There are other interesting things to do in the area such as Knapp Castle so if you combine these with the caves it is worth the drive.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Great site.  The paintings have been preserved by a less than cool iron grating but it does the job of keeping the crazies away from the art.  Nice day trip and you can combine with a lunch trip to Cold Springs Tavern.  Limited parking and mobility.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Worth it. Paintings of undetermined age. Glad they are protecting the site. Right next to the road. Go when the fog has lifted for some great scenic views.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: While the road is narrow and we gripped our seats the last 2 miles, getting up close to original Indian art in its true location was worth it. We followed it by a trip to the SB mission and learned even more about this tribe.  *Not a place for small children that want to run

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Long windy one way road, leading to a small, less than impressive cave, locked with a metal gate, that has only a small window to see the painting. Very limited parking, for 1 maybe 2 cars.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: We enjoyed the gorgeous views as we made our way up and down the mountain.  Unlike some of the other reviews, we did not find the drive frightening.  Everyone has different tolerance levels.  The historic cave paintings were beautiful. We thought this attraction was awesome.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Ridiculous and potentially dangerous road to get to...what? Sorry, but this a contrived historical site. It's true some Indian tribes were / are known for their historical art, cave paintings, pottery etc. The Chumash were not. They sparsely populated Ventura and Santa Barbara

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: We all absolutely loved visiting this historical site. The drive up and down the mountain is exhilarating! At one point we were up in the clouds and felt a clear temperature change. This is absolutely worth the drive. Other reviewers knocking this down because of the drive

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: The road is truly a scary experience.  Only room for one vehicle and few places where people can get by.  We had several close calls with vehicles coming down where we were fortunate to find places to squeeze by.  The hills are steep.  One wrong turn = quick death.  We saw the

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: There is a single very narrow road branching off from 254 in the Ynez valley leading out of Santa Barbara. The road is extremely windy with many hairpin and blind loops. There are walls of rocks in many places and the elevation is remarkably steep. If your vehicle does not

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: The Chumash Native Americans were well known for their art.  Lamentably this has not always been appreciated but the remarkable polychrome art of Painted Cave is somehitng all can appreciate and care for.  Our cultural heritage is of irreplaceable value.  This is a place to

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: I would like to say that I enjoyed this park, but the road is so narrow that there is really only room for one car going up or down and not a lot of room to move over if a car is coming down. I would have liked to see the caves, but I the narrow and winding road was too much.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: It's not work risking your life. It's a one vehicle road. Winding. Blind curves. No parking at the site. Would not recommend anyone to visit this site.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: The painted cave is the chief attraction of this teeny weeny state park. The paintings are vivid, surprisingly so, and kept behind bars so modern mouth-breathers don’t add new graffiti to the ancient Chumash graffiti. Also, of note, Tom Clancy’s house (formerly Joe Cocker’s) is

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: I am so glad these paintings are being protected for everyone's enjoyment. Parking is limited to two or three spots depending on the size of the vehicles. There is a short stairway to the caves. Good for all ages.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: Take the time to explore the Chumash Painted Cave State Historic site.  It offers a look into the history of the Chumash Indians that once occupied the area and left some of their art work behind.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: How often do you get to see native America cave paintings? Off the beaten track and (sadly) enclosed behind a protective fence. Nonetheless they are really cool and you will not find a lot of tourists here.

POI_name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
POI_address: Painted Caves Road, Santa Barbara, CA
POI_reviews: The road up to the cave is narrow, steep and winding and a lot of fun to drive. There's only a pull off large enough for one or two cars at the site. The opening to the cave is blocked by an iron gate but it has holes large enough to take pictures through. I found it sad that

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Unique wine tasting experience run by a resident alien from Australia.  We had a great time and the Area 51 memorabilia was fun to explore.  You will have an out of this world experience here, from what we saw......or did we see really see it?

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Wines were average and the “pilot” more interested in the movie on the big screen than on sharing the story of the winery.  Nothing memorable here.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Who doesn't like wines named using alien references?  Our Uber driver Markus told us we needed to go here are see Martin, so we did!  We had a great time and enjoyed some really good wines.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: This was a stop on The Urban Wine Trail card.  Really enjoyed the wine and Tony was very informative.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: A great little wine tasting gem in the heat of Santa Barbara.  We tried 5 wonderful wines and got to learn about each one. Super casual, down to earth and nice to try something quirky.  Martin was so inviting. Loved it!  Walked away with some great bottles. Thank you

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Cute little spot! We ordered 2 individual glasses rather than the tastings since I only like white wine and they don’t have a white only tasting (although I overheard a guy next to me that they were able to accommodate and give him a second tasting of a wine he liked rather than

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Love this tasting room! The wines are quite decent and the names of the wines are just pure fun! Very enjoyable tasting experience, love the guys here do not take themselves too serious. Highly recommend to get yourself lost in an alien world.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: We spent an afternoon doing a walking wine tour. Area 51 was our favorite stop. The employees were very friendly and down to earth. They were knowledgeable and did not rush us like some of the others. The wine was delicious and reasonably priced.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: My husband wanted to go to this Winery basically because of the name! Cozy little winery not far from the Wharf. Excellent wines and fun accessories to but with Area 5.1 on them.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: My husband and I took some time away from the family events to spend some quality time together at this establishment. The service was good, cheese plate excellent, the wine reasonably priced and pretty good. We each tasted and decided to purchase 2 bottles. We were

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Stopped in here during our urban wine trail tour of SB.  Good wines and a friendly and engaging staff with a laidback vibe.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: They've chosen a sci-fi theme at Area 5.1 winery in the Funk zone which is fine by us.  The wine was actually quite good.  We got there right at closing and the girl serving us didn't make us feel rushed at all, so that was above and beyond.

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: We loved spending an afternoon in "Funk Town".  The winery tasting rooms are so much fun.  We loved Area 5.1!  Great wine tasting experience.  If you like varitials, you will be so happy!  Affordable and Fun

POI_address: 137 Anacapa St Unit B, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-1848
POI_reviews: Unpretentious bartenders and funky decor. All wines were good but the red blends were my favorite. At $12 for 5 wines, you can't beat it!

Came here early on a Saturday morning, hoping to visit the burial site of actress Virginia Cherrill.  However, the large mausoleum appears to be the only part off limits during the Covid era.  We took advantage of our time here visiting the gravesites of several famous

head over to the cemetery and ride around. It's a pretty good size property so covering by two wheels allows you to see the grounds easily. Stop every now and then and read the tombstones. What's really nice is that most of the tombstones are flat on the ground/grass so you get
One of the most serene places one can go, in Santa Barbara or anywhere. Some very old markers here give you a feel for the local history. This picture may say it all.
This place is just stunning in every single way location beauty entrance landscape and the way it’s maintained and manicured
Beautiful, some exquisite monuments: But a waste of view on the dead.... Seriously, you could see & heat the ocean from up here....
The Santa Barbara Cemetery is located on a cliff looking over the Pacific Ocean.  A peaceful place to remember both the meaning and beauty of life.

What a beautiful and quiet spot.  I have family here going back 5 generations.  They keep it up beautifully and the chapel is beautiful as well.  There is some great history on some of the old tombstones.    My only request would be that they make the section markers bigger.

I visit friends who died way too young.  This is a beautiful site, nd if you want views and quiet, a fine visit.  It is also a solemn, sad place for honoring those who have passed, especially those who were so you g. It is well jept, and if you are looking for a last parking
This is not your usual cemetery.  The grounds are located within the city overlooking the ocean and beaches below. It`s a tranquil and pretty place albeit one where many are buried.

Stopped in here while we were biking to Montecito. Beautiful grounds, a mixture of garden memorials and headstones with a few mausoleums to boot. It's a big space to walk around as we were not allowed to ride our bike. Prime Real Estate alright.

I was on a mission to find my great grandfathers grave and his father's also. Went into the office,The gentleman there looked up all my information and took the time to take us out to where he was buried. Very nice and helpful people. Thank you again.

The SB Cemetery is the a beautiful resting place for loved ones. The bluffs are one side mountains on the other. It is a gorgeous place just to wander around and look at headstones. both my parents are buried here.

Set atop the bluffs of Santa Barbara's waterfront Santa Barbara Cemetery is beautifully serene. They do offer services if you are in need of that, but if you just want to visit then you'll be glad you did. I like to look for names of famous locals like Leadbetter and Stork. See

This is a wonderful old cemetery that is still in full operation.  It is very unique as cemeteries go, with its magnificent location perched atop a seaside cliff in Montecito overlooking the ocean, mountains and city, as well as its unusual architectural features, including one

We were staying at Fess Parker Doubletree and I'd read that he was buried at this cemetery, so we drove up to find his grave.  The cemetery has sweeping views of the water and the mountains, as one of the highest points in the city. There are lots of interesting epitaphs to

Gracious, serene, old-fashioned luxury graveyard, mausoleums and urn rooms. OK, not everyone appreciates graveyards, but this one has class. Above ground private mausoleums with the family names Firestone, Duryea, Halliburton and the like, hint of a time when Santa Barbara was a

The views from the Santa Barbara Cemetery are fabulous. The ground keeper was very helpful as I am an old movie buff and wanted to see where Ronald Coleman was buried. Fess Parker is buried there as well. May sound morbid, but I find the views and the area peaceful.

So, my mom and  dad are buried there.  Then, my husband died and his ashes are interred there.  Then my girlfriend's mom passed away and her ashes are with her dad in a military grave.  When I was a little kid (8-9) my best friend Diana and I would walk down the beach and climb
Located in scenic Montecito with a view of the ocean (not that you'll need it.) You too can be hob knobbin with Oprah and Ty Warner in these stately yet cozy dirt beds.

This cemetery is charming enough to be on the tour I give to visitors to SB.  The same tour that includes our Andalusian Courthouse and the Queen of the Missions and Francheschi Park.  Cypress carved by the wind into natural art perch on the bluff above Butterfly Beach and shade

We visited this for the first time (although we have been to SB dozens of times), and thought it was a wonderful place.  There are a few individuals of note buried here, but mostly it is fun to wander around--the cemetery has been here a long time.  You can also peek across the
If you have to visit, it's most likely a sad part of your day.  But, the beauty here may give you some peace.

It seems strange to recommend a cemetery as a tourist spot, but this sacred place, perched on a cliff overlooking the channel islands and the blue Pacific, is a beautiful opportunity to meditate, walk, sit and pray, or just commune with the spirits.

While staying at the Doubletree near Shoreline Park I went for an early morning walk and decided to walk up to the cemetery. This is a gorgeous piece of property that overlooks the Pacific and the central coast. I met the caretaker/manager who was very pleasant and encouraged me

This is one of the most beautiful places in an already beautiful city! Talk about prime real estate! It's worth a visit, just to see some of the famous people who are buried here, but mostly just to enjoy the view.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: Accidentally happened upon this restored house while wandering about in arcades off of State Street.  The house is named after the family who originally lived there -- de la Guerra -- and is a charming restoration.  Tickets to this house get you into the Presidio as well.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: Though it was a brief visit, our family encountered this museum via our compelling experience with the Santa Barbara Urban Adventure Quest. This Spanish family founded the city of Santa Barbara.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: Wonderful place to visit if your into 1700’s history of Spanish rule of California. Interesting information to read and recreation of life in the Presidio. Almost free to visit and you can take your time. Highly recommend visiting this site if you’re into history.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: We could only walk around and peek into the great open doors.  I know the history would be fascinating.  Next time, a full tour for sure!!!!

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: It was fascinating to see the history of the area come to life. It was a self guided tour but easy to see history come alive. It was nice to be able to spend the amount of time we wanted to spend without being rushed. It is a definite must see location.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.
POI_address: 15 E de La Guerra St, Santa Barbara, CA 93101-2217
POI_reviews: Walking tour of historic downtown Santa Barbara today with my wife and Sister. The visitor center hostess did a great job of telling us the history of the site and showed us a very well down video of the home site. It’s a must visit site for anyone living or visiting the city.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_reviews: Another of Santa Barbara's restored historic sites. This one was once the home of the renowned De La Guerra family during the old Spanish days. Quick to see and enjoy. It's about a 21 second walk above State st. on De La Guerra street . It's just across the street from City Hall

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_reviews: This is a great place to go to get a feel of what it would have been like to be a part of the garrison stationed in Santa Barbara way back when. Very nicely put together. One can really get a feel of what it was like to live in that time.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

POI_description: This restored 19th-century adobe building captures the authentic feel of Santa Barbara of old.

We went to Oreana's for a pre-wedding party. It was a blast, and the wine was great, the service was great.
Interesting wine choice available here including Portuguese varieties. Nice vibe and people as well. Good value place as $13 for a flight tasting including all 5

That is what first caught our attention.  The live music.  Outside seating, and lots of open space to taste and explore the wines.  Definitely going back!

POI_description: Ideal in the spring, the falls and the hike to the falls offers much for the visitor.
POI_reviews: This was the most incredible hike I have taken in the United States, aside from John Muir trial or some other trails in Yosemite.  The beginning of the hike doesn't seem incredibly interesting, though you get a grand view of the city and ocean from above.  The real fun starts
Went for a walk and checked this place out.  Very interesting and made you kind of think about what it was like back at that time period

Ever wonder where all the western carriages and stage coaches live when they're not in a parade?  This is the place!  But there's more... This is a terrific colorful venue for most any event. Check it out!
Experience early Santa Barbara at this recreation of old western town. See rare carriages and art from "The old days".

If you are looking for an off the beaten path museum with lots of real local history, this is the place. I love this gem of local pride and history. It is so much more than carriages, an authentic look into Santa Barbara's past and present. Don't miss it!

These remarkable carriages are taken out for the annual Fiesta Parade in August which is the biggest and most beautiful horse parade in the USA.There are also silver studded saddles on display. Many belonged to historical early Santa Barbara families.

This was like stepping back in time and it's FREE!  Some of the items on display are antique saddles, chaps, equestrian tack, a covered wagon, an antique horse drawn steam powered fire engine, and at least 35 more horse drawn conveyances manufactured between 1850 and 1911. If

Free Parking.  Free Admission.   On top of that, you have never seen such an assortment of horse-drawn carriages in one place.   Very small, you get through it in 45 minutes or less - just don't overlook the (beyond the bathroom) corridor to the rental dining hall, where the

My Sister-in-law rented this museum for my brother's 70th birthday.  The event space accommodated about 175 people with round dinner tables easily.  The museum staff helped us hire a piano player, bartenders, servers.  We had a band and the dance floor was hopping.  Loved the

Being from the Midwest and growing up watching cowboy movies, this was a lot of fun for me. I was amazed at the workmanship on the saddles, spurs, chaps, etc. It was also enjoyable to get a close up look at some of the modes of transportation. Just glad it's no longer necessary
the carriage house museum is like stepping back in around the santa barbara area it is a great time for the whole family. walking distance from the beach and harbor
This unique compilation of equestrian memorabilia houses a wide array of western horse related items and stores many of the beautiful saddlery used in the famous Fiesta
A fantastic collection of early California western and Mexican artifacts and carriages from the Ranchero days of California's history.

Santa Barbara has one of the largest collections of antique, horse drawn carriages in the United States. They are all brought out for Old Spanish Days and used during the massive parade. Located near the beach, the museum is free, accessible, and a look back into the history of

I have been here several times for High School Class reunions.  The building is great for a party and also contains historical transportation vehicles for Santa Barbara.  These are seen in the yearly Fiesta Parade in August.

This museum was built by the locals and continues to be updated. It houses the oldest and the most horse saddles in the country. Used in the Santa Barbara Fiesta parade, the saddles and old carriages are quite historical. This facility can also be rented for parties, weddings,

If you like western and ornate saddles and bridles this place will keep you interested for an hour or so. If you're looking for a meaningful collection of Western art, don't be thinking Maynard Dixon. If you hope to see a number of interesting carriages, you got it. If you hope

On the other side of Santa Barbara sits a hidden gem. This museum is chalk full of carriages and beautiful examples of clothing from the Spanish Festivals. I am not sure how much more they can fit in. I was staying at the Best Western and it was only a 5 minute walk.

A bit off the beaten tourist track, this small museum is a gem if you're interested in getting a feel for the old west.  Stagecoaches, saddles, carriages, you name it, they've got it.  This museum is well worth the visit.

If you need a cheap venue for a party, this place is great.  Management is easy and you can decorate however you choose.  I'd stick with the western theme, bring in the cowboys and kick up your heels.  It's fun to see the museum and all the old carriages too.
Great to take children to show them how the west was conquered by the various coaches/carriages that made their way out West. Free Admission. A 30 minute sojourn that's worth the stop.

Don't know how I missed this museum on our last visit since it was only a block from our Inn.  Small, interesting, historic and novel.  QWuick stop at own pacewith a well done presentation of old Cal relics.

I acted in a documentary video which we shot here and other historic locations in Santa Barbara. The carriage museum is really well done with a nice old Western bar set, a stagecoach and many other artifacts of the West. Free parking. Located next to the baseball fields and

Santa Barbara is known for its colonial Spanish history--and celebrates it with the annual Fiesta. The Carriage Museum on lower Bath St near the beach houses the Fiesta regalia of saddles, carriages and historical items that brings the past alive. Craftsmanship, showmanship,

I'd lived in the area for many years before I took the opportunity to visit the Carriage Museum... and then wondered why I didn't visit it sooner! There are some amazingly beautiful examples of "the old west" including a Silver Saddle and perfectly conditioned carriages.

Saw a sign for this museum on a walk down to the beach from our hotel.  Thought we would stop and check it out.  What a cool museum about our history.  All sort of different carriages,  saddles,  and old guns.  Take the time to check this place out if you get a chance.   Only

I didn't know what to expect, but when we walked in I knew instantly. Wagons of all shapes and sizes from hearses to baby carriages. An overall western frontier feel. Rifles and saddles line the wall, along with chaps and spurs. The western town is really cool to see, and if you

This museum really has more saddles than carriages.  You can look at them and follow the evolution of saddle styles over the years.  It also has an excellent display of saddles with silver mountings which were probably parade saddles. The entire perimeter of the inside walls is

It's a little known spot in Santa Barbara even for the locals but it's a treasure and an exciting look at the way things were.  The collection of saddles and tack,  the Ed Borein art work, the old carriages and stage coaches are among the things to see.  It's also available for

On a rainy day in Dec. we took the kids to this museum and came out 2 1/2 hours later - with great understanding of the Santa Ynez Valley, visions of stage coaches in our heads and lots of ideas about life in the early days.
Located adjacent to the Inn by the Harbor, a great selection of restored carriages and stage coaches.

Huge surprise! We thought it was small but not! This museum is large and fun and had many carriages and western wear, saddles decorationed in silver.  The back room is a design set of a western street scene. We spent a good hour checking out, up close the many different
